regions.text:
Fig.2 Visualization of classification and prognostic network. a Six
classic categories of HCC tissue, including normal liver tissue, por-
tal area, fibrous tissue, immune cells, tumor region and hemorrhage/
necrotic tissue were labeled in both H&E staining slides (left) and
segmentation images (right). b t-SNE analysis for visualization of
six tissue categories. c The ROC curves of identification precision of
each category in the testing dataset. d Normalized confusion matrix
for the classification network. e C-indices of the optimal models in

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Development of a deep pathomics score for predicting hepatocellular carcinoma recurrence after liver transplantation/crops_ordered/page_06/region_3_text.png
regions.text:
5-year RFS (Fig. 3d, g, SIE, F). Specifically, the AUC val-
ues of 5-year RFS were 0.781 and 0.814 in the training and
validation cohorts, respectively. Patients with lower DPS
had longer RFS and a lower recurrence risk in both cohorts
(Fig. 3e, f, h, 1). Furthermore, the combination of DPS with
the Milan criteria and UCSF criteria enabled a better sur-
vival discrimination for LT patients (Fig. S3).

regions.text:
each tissue category. f Cox regression analysis for risk scores of six
tissue categories. g Attention heatmaps for visualization of HCC tis-
sues. HCC hepatocellular carcinoma, t-SNE t-distributed stochastic
neighbor embedding, AUC area under curve, ROC receiver operating
characteristic, C7 confidential interval, NLT normal liver tissue, PA
portal area, /C immune cells, H&NT hemorrhagic/necrotic tissue, TR
tumor region, FT fibrous tissue

regions.text: Prognostic predictors of RFS in LT datasets

regions.crop_image_path: /mnt/sh_flex_storage/home/zehanyu/repos/GPT-Paper/pdfs/cancer_review/Development of a deep pathomics score for predicting hepatocellular carcinoma recurrence after liver transplantation/crops_ordered/page_06/region_6_text.png
regions.text:
Cox proportional hazards regression analysis was performed
to explore the independent predictors for RFS in the LT
cohort (Table $3). Fourteen candidates were proven to be
significant in the univariate analysis and were then evaluated
with multivariate Cox regression. The multivariable analysis
revealed that the RETREAT score [13] (HR 1.353, 95% CI
